Review: We read about Stone Island on another review and took our family, and LOVED it!  We went from a cruise ship that ported in Mazatlan and simply walked there. We exited the marina area, turned left and walked down the street a few blocks until we hit an intersection, crossed the street and walked straight along the gravel road until we found a small ferry and went over. I believe it cost $3 per person round trip. There was someone there waiting for tourists to try and talk us into sitting in his chairs, but we went a bit further to El Velero restaurant, sat in some lounge chairs on the beach for free, ordered some drinks, and had a great time. The kids played in the sand and ocean while we ate fresh cannolis. There was also a message therapist/chiropractor named Sonia outside Estebin restaurant (just prior to El Velero) who was great! This beach was our favorite stop of all the ports. We enjoyed this way more than touring Mazatlan itself with an overpriced tour.

Titulo: Beautiful area close to cruise terminal
Review: We picked this bean from aa review on Trip Advisor and it did not disappoint. A short 10-15 min walk from cruise terminal to water taxi, $3 pp round trip (they collect tickets on the return trip),  so many restaurants to choose from and we just got some drinks and nacho and no charge for the chairs. Beach are was so wide, tons of room. Plenty of people just laid in the sand.  There are several vendor that try and sell their goods, but not too pushy. Great relaxing day

Review: Love this piece of Mazatlan- actually an Isla across from the harbour of Mazatlan.If on a cruise ship you simply step outside the terminal gate and turn left.Walk about three blocks and down a gravel road to the Embarcadero.Pay 3.00 and get a “returno” ticket , walk down the wharf and onto a “Panga”which will whisk you across to the Isla in about five minutes.Once on the Isla simply cross the road and walk down onto the beautiful beach that runs for miles.There are a number of beach style eat/ drink establishments along the way.Highly recommend El Velero for very good food off a wide variety of menu offerings.Same for drinks. You can eat at your  lounge chair under your umbrella or at the restaurant.Your choice, great service and pricing and they do not charge for beach chairs , unlike some other venues.We had a great day and have agreed to return in the future to bask in the sun once more.

Review: I loved the people and the island it's like going back in time. However....after seeing SO many stray animals there as I seemed to be the only one feeding them. I asked around and no one gets their animals fixed even when the local animal rescue group pays 3k in US to get the mobile clinic there. THEN  to find dead carcasses on our walk ...some of the people there will put POISON out in meat to "control the population ". I personally will not go back and spend any of my money there. Inhumane and just stupid. I noticed alot of US and Canadian citizens renting there hopefully they will get involved.

Review: We walked around downtown Mazatlan on our own and enjoyed seeing this cathedral while we were in the old town. Its yellow color stands out as you walk by, and the interior has various nice checkerboard patterns. It wasn't as cool, temperature-wise, as some European cathedrals we've visited, but there were electric fans running on a hot day that kept the interior comfortable. We spent about 10 minutes sitting inside and admiring our beautiful surroundings.

Titulo: Located across from Plaza Principal, it gives you a sense of unity
Review: The Basilica is located in the central of Mazatlan. Built on an ancient Indian Temple, it stands out with its Baroque, Moorish and Gothic influences. It has an eclectic, yet very beautiful look. The best place to view the Catedral, is from Vista Hermosa up on the hillside. Virgin de la Purisima Conception is the Patron saint of Mazatlan, and you can see her above the altar in a protective pose. Due to the French trying to (unsuccessfully) recolonialize Mexico in the 1860's, The Catedral wasn't finished until 1899. The Catedral has a very impressive organ that was built in Paris by Aristide Cavaille-Coll. He was probably one of the best organ builders during this time. I was told that the foundation of the Basilica was paid by the Jewish Community of Mazatlan. Being grateful for the donation they incorporated the Star of David on each of the 28 stainglassed windows. Opposite from the Basilica there is a park with its own history. Surrounded by a lot of foliage, its a great place to find some shade.
Atraccion: Catedral Mazatlan Basilica De La Inmaculada Concepcion

Titulo: Beautiful Cathedral Worthy of a Visit
Review: The Catedral was one of the stops on our city tour. It is a beautifully designed church with easy access to both exterior and interior photographs. We were there on a Holy Day of Obligation so there were frequent masses well attended by local churchgoers. The interior of the church has spectacular gothic like arched ceilings with many statues and side altars. It sits right across the street from a central plaza which was busy with visitors. It also had many interesting backdrops for photographs. Food vendors were present.
Atraccion: Catedral Mazatlan Basilica De La Inmaculada Concepcion

Titulo: Great Dolphin Encounter But Pricey Photos
Review: We had an amazing time at this dolphin encounter! We purchased the ride package which we didn’t spend a lot on due to having vouchers that covered the cost of 3.5 of 5 people in our group. The encounter did last only 30 minutes unless you purchase a higher level package of course. We could not take our own photos and they had photographers taking them for us. The photo packages charge a fee per person which made our lowest package cost $254 for 5 people. If it were not for our low cost for the dolphin encounter we would not have purchased a photo package. However, we did purchase them and the photos are nice but very pricey!

Titulo: Visit the restaurant at the acquarium!
Review: There were 6 adults in our party, and we visited the interactive acquarium one afternoon. It was a little tricky to find, as it is located in the Isla shopping district and is not clear from the main road. It was between Louis Vuitton and Johnny Rockets. The acquarium itself was nice and mostly air-conditioned. The dolphins were outside. We missed the dolphin show, which I believe was only twice a day. The real surprise was the restaurant. We decided to grab cocktails, and they were the best we had during the entire trip. We had eaten lunch elsewhere, but we were brought fresh chips and 3 different types of "salsa," all complimentary. We found room in our bellies, and the chips and dip seemed to be authentic Mexican. The service was top-notch! The restaurant overlooked the dolphin pool, and we got to witness families getting their pictures taken with the dolphins. I recommend this stop during your trip to Cancun.

Review: Sea Trek was amazing they put a bubble helmet on you and you go down about 20 ft under the water. The fish are swimming all around you. The puffer fish were huge way bigger than I thought they were. We got to pet a Manta Ray and they fed the puffer in front of us. It was really cool, and the scuba divers guiding you around were super friendly and helpful. They really made it such an enjoyable experience and you felt safe with their guidance. When we finished there off for our instructions for the dolphin encounter. This was also amazing because there were 6 people instead of 4 we got a free fin ride along with 40 minutes in the pool with the dolphins and the superman push where two dolphins push you out of the water by your feet. It was an incredible experience and I loved every minute of it. Again the staff for the experience were so amazing and gave very clear instructions and I really appreciated learning about each individual dolphin we were playing with. After our fun with the dolphins we toured the aquarium it was small but very cool. I didn't take pictures cause we were wearing go pros. After that we did some shopping at the gift store. All in all it was well worth the money and an unforgettable experience.  The staff at every attraction were super friendly and just an amazing experience all around.

Review: La Isla Shopping Village was a great surprise during our trip to Cancun! It’s a beautiful open-air shopping center with a relaxed, vacation vibe and a fantastic location right by the water.There’s a great variety of shops – from international brands to local boutiques – so whether you're after fashion, souvenirs, or skincare, you'll find something. The prices are very reasonable, actually quite similar to what you'd expect in Europe, which makes it easy to enjoy some guilt-free retail therapy.The staff in the shops were all super friendly and helpful, without being pushy – a nice touch that made browsing really enjoyable.Bonus points for the setting: the canals, fountains, and waterfront restaurants make it feel more like a resort than a mall.Whether you’re shopping, dining, or just strolling with a gelato, La Isla is definitely worth a visit if you're in Cancun!

It’s a beautiful open-air shopping center with a relaxed, vacation vibe and a fantastic location right by the water.There’s a great variety of shops – from international brands to local boutiques – so whether you're after fashion, souvenirs, or skincare, you'll find something. The prices are very reasonable, actually quite similar to what you'd expect in Europe, which makes it easy to enjoy some guilt-free retail therapy.The staff in the shops were all super friendly and helpful, without being pushy – a nice touch that made browsing really enjoyable.Bonus points for the setting: the canals, fountains, and waterfront restaurants make it feel more like a resort than a mall.Whether you’re shopping, dining, or just strolling with a gelato, La Isla is definitely worth a visit if you're in Cancun!.

Maybe next time we’ll look into the Ferris wheel. You’d probably get some nice elevated photos of the mall and the lagoon.

Titulo: Shopping, entertainment, restaurants, bars, Skywheel and even more
Review: Wednesday 30th October and we took the local bus from our Hotel Riu Palace Los Americas to the extensive shopping village, La Isla Cancún. The bus fare was 12 Pesos (roughly fifty pence).It's located in the Hotel Zone, along Nichupte and Bojórquez Lagoon.Would not say we visited here, it was more of an expedition and not just a quick in and out.We started off in La Botique Palacio, this was definitely high end shopping with stores like Louis Vuitton, Bottega Veneta, Balenciaga, Marc Jacobs, Giorgio Armani, Gucci and many others. There were armed guards on duty in this sector, in fact when we were here, there were more guards than shoppers.There were other well know brands such as Abercrombie & Fitch, Prada, Lacoste and many more. Not all of the stores are high end and branded, there are numerous souvenir shops and other outlets to be visited.There are a wide variety restaurants, bars, coffee shops and other eateries. Senor Frogs bar and restaurant, McDonald's and Starbucks are some of the many food and drink outlets. There are both indoor and outdoor dining courtyards.There were a series of bridges that spanned waterways that linked various sections of the complex. Along one of the canals was a blue and white stripped lighthouse, it is actually a restaurant.We walked along the Coloured Walk (reviewed separately) which links two areas of the complex.Throughout the complex there are a number of features and fountains including Ballerina Fountain and La Isla Circle There a number of other attractions to be visited here including the Aquarium, with it's interactive touch tanks and over a thousand species on display.It is also home to the Cancún Wax Museum with it's exhibits of the rich and famous.Ripley's Believe it or not is also here with hundreds of unbelievable but true artifacts, interactive games and stories. There is also a Casino The Skywheel with it's thirty-five gondolas is a standout feature and at seventy metres high it dominates the skyline and is visible from some distance. The fare is in the region of $15 (US).

Review: Don’t go-  La Isla is going through construction and I made mistake of taking visiting family to see the sunset and have dinner.  We missed sunset because the parking deck elevator didn’t work, had to wheel visitor through the down lane of deck.  Eventually around front located wheelchair access to shopping area.  Missed the sunset 🌅 Wanted to get cash for the great saxophone player after dinner except every cash machine in La Isla was NOT working!After dinner returned to deck for another nightmare.  After splitting up family and someone walking up deck for car we discovered the ticket payment machine was broken too!After picking up wheelchair visitor from sidewalk we approached parking booth.  Held us for 20 minutes because the payment machine was cash only because of broken machine!  We didn’t have much cash between us.  After requesting a supervisor, no one arrives for 20 minutes so one visitor asked if they could transfer money to the employee and they pay?  Yes, and after sending money to employee we were able to leave.  I’m definitely posting this to TripAdvisor because no one else should experience this in paradise. The management should not be charging for parking when elevators and ticket pay kiosk aren’t working and construction barriers and materials are in parking deck.  Looked like greed to me!

Titulo: Absolutely gorgeous. Soft sand, blue water and the beautiful sunrise.
Review: We stayed in Playa Morelos, but managed to visit Cancún beach early one more before handing back in our rental car. We drove the whole strip and ended up stopping at Playa Delfines. At 7am there was LOTS of free parking and barely anyone on the beach. It was absolutely gorgeous. With the soft sand, blue water and the beautiful sunrise. It was a little windy when we went so the waves were quite large and we didn’t end up swimming as planned, since we had kids with us. We walked a bit of the beach looking at the shells that had washed ashore. And fully plan to return with life jackets for our kids so we can swim and enjoy the waves/beach. It was absolutely stunning.

Titulo: Free Beach with Free Thatch Shade Umbrellas
Review: Free beach. Free parking. Sure, the parking is on the sandy side of the road because the lot is so tiny but it’s all free. What’s more, there are dozens of large thatched umbrellas to sit under (again for free). I saw tons of families on the beach with our family of 5 that included three teens. There is a bathroom but expect to pay the guy for toilet paper. There is also seaweed but much less than Plays Langosta that we visited the next day. Bring your own food and drinks, but I saw several guys walking the beach and selling drinks, fruit, ceviche, etc. The Cancun sign is up in the parking lot which increases traffic. Since the hotels have their beaches basically locked up, this is our #1 choice of Cancun beach.

Titulo: Would not want to spend time here - only came here to catch the ferry  - not impressed
Review: Monday 28th October and we were here to catch the ferry to Isla Mujeres. It's name translates as the Beach of the Turtles, we did not see any.Overall this crescent shaped beach, with it's white sand, is enclosed by rugged rock formations at one end and a wooden jetty at the other. The beach is washed by the waters of the Caribbean Sea. The ferry pier has split the beach into two sections.The beach on the right hand side of the pier, when facing out to sea, is the smaller of the two. To the rear of this beach there are a number of bars with seating and tables on the sand. There were a handful of sunbeds and umbrellas as well. This section of the beach is enclosed by the ferry pier at one end and rocky headland at the other. At the time of our visit this side of the beach was rather ugly looking with lots of seaweed piled up along the waterfront.The left hand side of the beach was the larger and cleaner side. It sits between the ferry pier and the wooden jetty at the far end. Nearby the pier there was a bar with seating and tables.There was a tent/gazebo along the beach which appeared to be some sort of emergency treatment centre (centro de atencion inmediata). When we were here people were using it as a sunshade.Towards the jetty there was a restaurant/bar with sunbeds and umbrellas along the beach.The beach is accessible by public transport or by walking from the nearby hotels.

Titulo: Pleasent beach with easy access to the Romantic zone.
Review: Playa de Los Muertos ... "Deadman’s Beach," named for the bones of the local indigenous people found buried in the sand, or after the legendary pirate raids on the nearby village, it depends who you believe. Lots of beach sports are played here overlooked by an assortment of excellent restaurants and bars that are a party haven for PV's LGBTQ travelers. The pier lights up at night, and is also the starting point for day fishing trips, and boat rides to the more private and secluded beaches. The little seahorse statue is worth a photo as it has been replacing three times, due to serious storms removing it. TIP: The beach has a strong current, parents with children please take extra precautions when swimming.If you found this review informative, please check the box below. Thank you.

Review: Wow!  Crazy place!  We walked down Basilio Badillo, and ended up at Los Muertos.  We walked out onto the famous pier, and local kids were jumping off.  It was a summer weekend so packed with locals and visitors alike.  You can rent water sports like paddleboards.  We meant to come back because it was one large insane party place, and looked so fun, but didn't have time to return.  Lots of beachfront eateries, and shopping on the street side of the restaurants.  I wouldn't want to stay here unless I was a young party person (in which case, yes please!), but it is a great place to visit for the day.  I'd like to see it lit up at night, too.  It was very gay friendly, and good for families too.  We walked up the beach all the way to The Marina.

Titulo: Great Vacation, Need to Know Mexico
Review: We’re a family of 5 with kids 10, 8 and 4. Haven’t been to Mexico in about 15 years. What a welcomed return!! We chose San Pancho as it seemed a little less busy than Sayulita and we were welcomed with a beach that boasted a great surf (bit sketchy for the kids so be wary) and so much beach space it was easy to forget there were others around us. The restaurant selection is great! We were here for 10 days and only ate at the same place once, and that was only because we loved it so much (La Ola Rica). We rented a home on Air BnB and got a car service to town from Puerto Vallarta. We will definitely be planning a trip back here and during that time will be able to give a 5 star rating. The only point right now is that San Pancho is a newer tourist place (again what we saw as a bonus) so it’s still a bit rough around the edges. So for those who are looking for a manicured holiday maybe just come here for a day trip. For those who are looking to speak Spanish (or in our case bumble through a few broken phrases), relax with barely anyone around, “live like a local”, have alone beach time, eat amazing food, hear great music, watch local shows, and sit in hot sun with no clouds allllll day long, then San Pancho is the place for you. A little research, some sense of adventure and flexible attitude and you’ll pleased as punch. Thank you San Pancho for a great vacation!

Titulo: Just beautiful, amazing and every other superlative
Review: We spent two weeks at the Riu Palce Pacifico, from from 27th January to 10th February. It is situated along the horseshoe shaped coastline of the Bay of Banderas, which measures about forty miles long and about 20 miles wide. The bay and it's waters receive natural protection from the mighty Sierra Madre mountain range which frames the bay, which is at the foot of the mountain range. We were reliably informed that it is the largest natural bay in Mexico. Due to the deep waters in the Bay, fishing there is reportedly some of the best in the world. It also hosts the frequent visitors, Humpback Whales and dolphins, sea turtles and rays reside here. A fellow guest informed us that they saw an alligator in the sea Almost on a daily basis, from our sunbeds on Playa Riu Palace Pacifico, we were treated to a display of whales and dolphins surfacing in the Bay. It was an amazing sight to see a whale splash down on the sea and then about 10 seconds later hear the booming sound of the whale hitting the water, brilliant. Our beach, Playa Riu Palace Pacifico, is a turtle conservation and nesting area for turtles. One day we were privileged to see a batch of turtles hatch, totally at the wrong time, and scurry towards the sea. Fellow holidaymakers, on the beach, provided protection on their way from the eagerly awaiting hungry pelicans. It is possible to take a boat tour, from Puerto Vallarta Harbour, to see whales. We could see numerous boats out at sea on a daily basis. It appeared that the boats would wait till a pod of whales was spotted and then speed to the area. A variety of water sports and activities, including wind surfing and boarding are popular in the Bay. Another wonderful sight is to sit with a cold beer and watch the sun set across the bay. Our room was on the 7th floor of the Hotel, sea facing, we were treated to some wonderful views of the Bay. It is possible to enjoy the Bay and all it has to offer directly from your sunbed. We did see slightly different views as we walked the beach, six and a bit kilometres in one direction and nearly three kilometres in the other. The City of Puerto Vallarta is within the Bay, it is an enjoyable experience to walk along the Malecon, see all the unusual statues and sculptures with the backdrop of this beautiful Bay.

Titulo: Fun and educational for the whole family
Review: We took the Bahia Allegre catamaran for a day in the Bay. The crew was the best!!! Safety first, and alot of fun. They offered breakfast, lunch and drinks. Alcohol was only available after we were done with all the activities. They included: snorkeling, Kayaking, paddle board, and swimming. All of that in the clean and beautiful water of the Bandera Bay.We saw dolphins and on the way back we saw a whale!!! Majestic, unforggetable time.There 12 in our group, ages 8 to 58, and we all had a wonderful time.Hats off to Luis and the lifeguard with 30 year experience on board. They were top notch, highly recommend this company.

Review: On Monday 16th April we took a speedboat ride across the Bay, from Nuevo Vallarta to Boca de Tomatlan and our return journey as part of our Vallarta Adventures outdoor activities tour. It was a wonderful travelling experience as our boat sped across the top of the water, we were able to appreciate the size of the Bay and the spectacular mountains and their domination of the skyline.This Bay is situated on the west-central coast of the Mexican Pacific coastline, and is about 65 miles long.We asked our Tour Guide if there were any whales or dolphins in the Bay, he advised us that there were none, they had moved on some weeks ago to different waters, so sadly we saw nothing.Puerto Vallarta, Bucerias and Punta Mita are the largest towns within the Bay, also home to Puerto Vallarta and Nuevo Vallarta marinas. It is a favourite tourist location and there are a large number of hotels, golf courses and condominiums along the Bay.We stayed in Nuevo Vallarta for 2 weeks and very much enjoyed the views of the Bay which is flanked on all land sides by imposing mountains, Sierras. They are Sierra Vallejo on the northern part, Sierra Cuale to the East and Sierra El Tuito to the south and southeast.These contribute to the stunning backdrop to the Bay.Local tour guides will have you believe it is the largest bay in the world, the reality is somewhere else is.

Review: We went on a snorkeling/whale-watching trip, and while the snorkeling wasn't great, the whale watching was amazing! It was mating season so we saw a lot of action. There was a group of about 10 of them in one spot! One whale came right up next to our little boat! We also went over to the Marieta Islands where we saw blue-footed boobies and other birds. It was great!

Titulo: one of the worlds most beautiful bays & city setting
Review: My friend & I took two day long trips out into Banderas Bay during our 10 day visit.   We took a Vallarta Adventures dive trip out to the Marrietas Islands and also a day luxury sailing day trip.  When returning from diving we were surrounded by the biggest school of dolphins I ever saw.  There were hundreds, and the captain stopped our boat so we could enjoy the amazing sight.  We also saw many frigate birds, both blue- footed and brown boobies, brown pelicans, and gulls.  A cruise on the bay is a must outing when visiting Puerto Vallarta.

Titulo: Many small villages and large towns
Review: Banderas Bay is home to a large number of towns and cities.  Much of the coastline is building up, but there are still smaller villages scattered about and they are always good to visit. North of Puerto Vallarta, which is the biggest city and just about center of the bay, you can drive to the smaller villages and towns.  Punta Mita & Bucerias are a couple of the larger areas and have interesting town centers.  They are worth a drive. South of Puerto Vallarta lie Mismaloya and Boca de Tomelin.  Mismaloya is tied to the movie "Night of the Iguana", although it has changed extensively since Elizabeth Taylor's visits. Bica is a thriving small port town; many water taxi routes using the port today.  boca is the last coastal town on the bay, from here the road cuts inland.  Any village to the south are accessed mainly by water taxi although a few have roads through the mountain originating mainly in El Tuito. The main villages along this stretch include Animas, Yelapa, Quimixto, Pizota, Conchas and Chimo. Yelapa is the largest of these and has water taxi service from los Muertos Pier in Puerto Vallarta.  It has a nice waterfall that can be hiked to, worthwhile (Pizota has a waterfall as well).  It also has a nice pier/dock...a few of the villages have none, necessitating a jump onto the surf from the water taxi.  Chimo collects passengers in a small canoe and transports them from the taxi to the beach. Quimixto is a fair sized settlement, Pizota has about 80 residents, Conchas is just 24 palapa style homes and Chimo residents number about 100.The water taxi ride is beautiful, taking just over an hour from Boca to Chimo, so days have heavy seas, so sit to the back of the boat if you can for a smoother ride. The taxi runs twice a day from Boca to Chimo, roughly 150 pesos each way (new rates may be in effect). Yelapa, Quimixto and Chimo have restaurants so they are good choices for day trips.  Pizota has a family or two who will cook if you give them advance notice--you may be eating in their homes. Most all the villages have some sort of accommodations available, Yelapa having the widest selection. Many places are listed on Airbnb or VRBO websites. This southern section of Banderas Bay is well worth exploring.

Titulo: Bay Of Banderas: The Jewel In The Crown Of Puerto Vallarta
Review: My  husband & I spent over a month enjoying views of Banderas Bay, this winter. We rented a cliff top condo in Conchas Chinas for the first half of of stay..This area was about a five minute bus ride from downtown PV. It was the area where the Sierra Madre Mountains cascaded down to meet the waters of Banderas Bay. We watched whales in the bay from our balcony. We had happy hours at Lindo Mar Resort & watched the sunset over Banderas Bay. We ate many meals on our balcony while we enjoyed its beauty & serenity. Our second condo was in an area just north of downtown PV. We were high on a hill & had expansive territorial Bay & city views. We spent hours on our balcony enjoying the marine action on the bay. Cruise ships, yachts, sailboats, pirate ships, fishing boats, parasailing, fireworks, seabirds, & more captured our attention during the day. Sunsets were glorious multicolored events. Truly magical!We were not content just to look a the dark blue water of Banderas Bay. We walked its shores along the Malecon. We ate & drank at waterside restaurants. We walked the beaches of Los Muertos, el Camerones, & Mismaoya. We swam in it. This 62 mile bay was truly the jewel in the crown of Puerto Vallarta. I look forward to spending another winter's month gazing at its beauty.

Review: Review for the thursday night markets here. A lot of booths here, mostly selling little trinkets and souvenirs. Some of the booths have similar or even identical stuff. The price initially offered is not cheap. I think it's pretty much expected you'll have to haggle a bit. It should be pretty easy to haggle it down to at least 50% of the original price. If you are persistent enough and have enough time and energy to haggle more, you can probably cut the price down even further. Whether that's worth it is up to you to decide.I was hoping that there would be more food stalls but I couldn't find any except for a few down at the tail end of the marina towards the south. We were pretty hungry by then but most of the restaurants were already full or booked out so we ended up taking a uber somewhere else for food.

Review: We had a wonderful experience at Playa Las Gemelas today. We wanted to go to a beach outside of PV proper and Yelapa seemed too far for two women traveling here for our first time. It was a Tuesday in November so it was quiet, which was welcomed. It seemed more locals, either from nearby towns or the condos on the beach. But the water was clean and clear with mild waves, the shells were gorgeous and the water temperature couldn't be beat. We Uber'd there instead of the bus. You're dropped on the side of the highway to take very steep and unkempt stairs down to the water (not handicap friendly), which opens up onto the beach. There, vendors make food, rent tables and chairs and have other fun things to look at / buy. You won't be disappointed.

Titulo: Almost all locals and away from touristy area
Review: We had a nice experience spending the afternoon relaxing here. Took an uber and they drop you off at a large staircase (may be difficult for elderly or small children to get down). Once you get to the bottom you’ll likely be approached by guys offering to rent you beach chairs and umbrellas. We didn’t bring anything other than towels so we paid for two chairs, a small table and umbrella for 350 MX pesos. They also sell fresh fruit and coconuts. We got there around 11am and it was still pretty empty/quiet but once 1pm hit it got very crowded with all locals. There are no bathroom or shower facilities so beware of that if planning a day.Overall I would recommend as it was a much better/cleaner area to swim in the ocean than the zona hotelera.

Titulo: Prepare to have your heart stolen by Baile Folklórico at Palacio de Bellas Artes
Review: Baile Folklórico at the Palacio de Bellas Artes is hands down one of the most beautiful and moving performances I’ve ever witnessed. From the very first drumbeat, I was completely captivated. The show is a vibrant celebration of Mexico’s diverse regions, with each dance telling a unique story through traditional footwork, colorful costumes, and dramatic choreography. You can truly feel the soul of Mexico come alive on stage.The venue itself, the Palacio de Bellas Artes, is breathtaking—its grand architecture makes the entire evening feel like a special occasion. I highly recommend dressing up a bit and making a night of it. If you're looking to experience authentic Mexican culture and artistry, this performance is unforgettable.

Review: The building is outstanding from the outside … located next to a park and with its own manicured gardens out front, it will make for lovely photos to remember your visit. The inside is art deco in design and is equally stunning. It appears to have spaces for exhibits, but there was a fee … there is a small FREE display just as you enter on the right … that was worth a look … It is not far from the main square and cathedral.

Small but elegant gardens lead the eye, the foot, and the person inevitably to a hugely impressive facade. A building to be proud of.

Titulo: Enjoy the audio tour of the murals
Review: Great way to see the muralists, beautiful architecture and stunning art. Angela Gurria show was tremendous. Big tip- ask an English speaking guide for the QR code for an English guided audio recording that describes the murals. Free and totally enhances the viewing and appreciation of the murals. Another trip is to take a break mid visit and have a beer or coffee or snack in the lovely cafe.

Review: I visited on a free Sunday otherwise I would not have been able to fit this into my trip. It was busy as expected so my advice is, avoid the free day if you can afford it. The art deco interior detail is wonderful, as usual the exterior and its features.The murals are huge and I loved taking them in at different levels.Saw some interesting art in the small exhibit rooms. Loved the 3D sectional model and technical drawings on top floor.Sadly unable to see the theatre room and my attempt to buy tickets to the ballet didn’t align date wise.Cafe and bookshop/souvenirs onsite.1.5hours happily spent here.Popped into Sears to get a view from across the street and to grab a bite at the 6th floor cafe but the queue was too long so I abandoned that idea.

Review: Great!Peaceful!Magestic!And very congested with tourists! We came here on an Uber ride, no need for a tour guide.Don’t forget, this is a church that does hold regular mass. It still requires visitors to practice respect toward the Catholic faith. This is a large property with two churches and the hill of Tepeyac. Make sure to take your time and stop and visit everything. Don’t feel intimidated with the stairs leading to El Cerro de Tepeyac, where Juan Diego saw the virgin mother. Once you get there, they have a souvenir section, a cemetery, which I didn’t get to see due to it being closed. You will also visit a small chapel. The chapel is where Virgin Mary tilma used to be. You’ll find a  souvenir shop and some street food vendors.From there, you can also take in a spectacular view of the city. Definitely well worth the short 15 minutes of steps up. The historic old chapel is also worth seeing, as it is gradually sinking. Its architecture is breathtaking.

Titulo: A Spiritual Uplifting Place Surounded by History...
Review: This is a special Basilica demonstrating the history of the conversion of native American people to the Christian Faith.  There are hundreds of years of religous art and architecture here.  This is a top 5 pilgramige site for Catholics.  Like all Chistian Churches it is open to all and free of charge.  It is best to begin at the La Villa Subway station for a nice view of the enterance.  The day long journey and walking includes the Basilica, the Blessing Station, hourly services, the Baptistry, 6 large historic Chapels, a Convent, the hill climb to the spring, 1000's religous paintings and bronzes, two museums, the fountains procession, the garden, the story telling clock tower and the miracle reveal.  The outwall has the Jesus's stations of the cross like Jerusalem in the Holyland.

Titulo: Basilica provided English speaking tour arranged ahead of time
Review: Ahead of our first-time visit, I booked a private tour for our group of 3 couples via the Basilica's website. Ms. Gabriela can be reached at visitasguiadas@inbg.mx - she is an English-speaking volunteer for the Basilica - she requests a very modest financial gift   be made at the Basilica office at the beginning of the Tour.  It was really worth it to have Gabriela's guided visit of the entire complex. Note, there are elevations to climb (3 in our group opted not to climb to the top of the hill to see the Parish of the Indians) but it is totally worth the effort! We are all Catholics and after our tour attended 4pm Mass in the old Basilica.At the conclusion of the tour, Gabriela gave each couple a packet of additional information. Note, you can NOT be late to her assigned time, again, because she is a volunteer. And we also chose to generously tip Gabriela for her time and guidance. Note, we had a wonderful private driver that day bring our group from the Anthropology Museum to the Basilica entrance and wait for us. He speaks very good English and drove a large vehicle comfortable for our 6. See my review of Gran Hotel for his contact information.Also, give yourself more than 2 hours (we spent 3 and I wish I had more time!) to visit.Lastly, please, please, please dress in a MODEST way as this is a place of consecrated churches.

Titulo: A must stop for any and all Christians.
Review: It is a pilgrimage for Catholics and a testimony for the unbelievers. You will see the evidence of the actual miracle,… for the faithful.  For skeptics, may be it is time to reconsider and explore the history and revisit the knowledge. Read about the miracle and the importance of this basilica, before your visit especially if you are not accompanied by a reputable tour guide.

Review: We were nine family members, visiting the Basilica, including young children, teens and grandparents.  We all loved it.  Parking was easy in the garage.  As soon as we arrived Mass was being celebrated so we took the opportunity to participate (Mass is celebrated every half hour).  It was so very moving to celebrate Mass in front of the image of Our Lady of Guadalupe.  Once Mass ended we went and rode the moving platform underneath the image that allows one to see the image closer.  We then spent too much time in the gift shop that’s in the lower rear of the Basilica.  The shop is very crowed.  You are better off going to one of the other official stores located on the grounds of the Basilica because there will be less crowded.  Finally we, without the grandparents, climbed to the top of the hill where one of the original churches that housed the image of Our Lady is located.  The view was beautiful as are the gardens and statues on the way up and down.  Don’t miss them!  Seeing Our Lady of Guadalupe in person is a beautiful, moving and uplifting experience.

Review: I was raised Catholic but no longer practice.  Still you needn't be religious to find that this site is worth the trip and an hour or two of your time.  It's really a huge complex.  The new basilica houses the image of the virgin, which is located behind the altar.  Visit all of the churches/chapels to get the complete picture and to enjoy the views of the city.

Titulo: Mexico's different cultures all under one roof
Review: For me, this is the best anthropological/cultural museum in the world.  They have artefacts on display from about all of Mexico's different groups from the Aztecs to the Zapotecs.  The signage also gives a great explanation (both Spanish and English) of how the objects fit into the cultures.  It's vast, and there are a lot of different groups covered, but you walk away with a much more in-depth understanding of these groups than you get at other museums.  It is not a place you breeze through in 30 minutes (and if you do as part of a city tour, that's a real shame), but you need at least 1/2 day if not a full day for the full impact.The curators have done a great job of laying out a pathway through the exhibits, starting to the right of the fountain on the ground floor as you enter.  You start there, and work your way around teh U-shaped complex.  Then head upstairs for more on modern Mexican indigenous tribes.In all, do not miss this on a trip to Mexico City.  It is a key to understanding Mexican culture and history.  Note that on Sundays, Mexican citizens get free admission, so it can be a bit more crowded than normal.  Also, tickets can be purchased ahead of time on your phone, or there are ticket booths that take cash or credit cards.

Review: This museum is as great as you would expect it to be. It's divided by region (Oaxaca, Mayan/Yucatan, Gulf, Norte, etc.). Be sure to wander outside; the museum does a great job of blending indoor and outdoor artefacts. Less than half the signs have English translations.There was an emphasis on human remains, and it was tastefully presented. Also, the section of the museum explaining archaeological excavation was straightforward and well done. Everything was beautifully lit and the museum scientists designed the flow extremely well.The second floor was completely closed.

Titulo: No insulated water bottles allowed here.
Review: I’m giving this museum 4 stars based on others reviews because unfortunately my daughter and I didn’t make it inside. I just wanted to let everyone know that if you go here with an insulated water bottle (ie metal) you will have to throw it away if you want to enter the museum. Review: One of the best archeological museums in the Western Hemisphere.  It is impossible to spend less than 3-4 hours here.  The Museum includes exhibits and reproductions inside its halls but also architectural models/buildings outside each pavilion as well.   Upstairs is an entire ethnographic section on the states in Mexico although much of this was closed on this visit.  There is a restaurant that serves breakfast and a coffee shop that had sandwiches.  Note the architectural design of the museum with its giant fountain/roof in the center of the complex.  It features prominently in many architecture books.  Since this museum sits in the Chaputapec park area, if you visit, plan on seeing other park attractions as well.

Review: The National Museum of Anthropology in Mexico City is an absolute treasure and a must-visit for anyone interested in history, culture, or anthropology. The museum is vast and houses an incredible collection that spans the rich and diverse history of Mexico, from pre-Hispanic civilizations to modern indigenous cultures.Each exhibit is beautifully curated, with detailed information (in both Spanish and English) that brings the artifacts to life. The museum’s centerpiece, the Aztec Sun Stone, is breathtaking, and the Maya Hall is equally impressive. The outdoor courtyards, with their iconic umbrella fountain, provide a tranquil break between exhibits.Plan to spend at least a few hours here—there’s so much to see that rushing through would be a disservice to the experience. Even if you’re not typically a museum person, the sheer scale and quality of the exhibits will captivate you. The museum is also very accessible, with clear signage, ramps, and elevators.Whether you're a history buff or just curious about Mexico’s past, this museum offers an unforgettable journey through time. Highly recommended!

The outdoor courtyards, with their iconic umbrella fountain, provide a tranquil break between exhibits.Plan to spend at least a few hours here—there’s so much to see that rushing through would be a disservice to the experience. Even if you’re not typically a museum person, the sheer scale and quality of the exhibits will captivate you. The museum is also very accessible, with clear signage, ramps, and elevators.Whether you're a history buff or just curious about Mexico’s past, this museum offers an unforgettable journey through time. Highly recommended!.

Titulo: The best museum in Mexico. Go even if you don't like museums.
Review: Incredible place. Do not miss it even if you aren't a museum person. This is a spectacular building designed with the observer in mind. The Stone of the Sun is here (used to be known as the Aztec calendar) and so many more amazing things. They have recreated scenes from many of the sites where the objects were found, which I think makes the artifacts more meaningful.

Titulo: Go if you have free time but don’t prioritize
Review: This is a lot of art but not very well displayed or curated. It made me think of that aunt who has collected a lot of things and displays them on every shelf in her house and then invites neighbors to see everything she has.  There is some good art but it’s hard to find the needles in the haystack. Carlos Slim needs to hire someone to tell him he shouldn’t display everything all at once.  On the upside, it’s free.

Titulo: Unique Building and an Interesting Mix of Art & History
Review: We visited Museo Soumaya while in Mexico City, and it was definitely worth the stop. The building itself is really eye-catching—super modern and unlike anything else around. It’s right next to Museo Jumex, so you can easily see both in one trip.As soon as you walk in, the space feels huge and open. Everything inside is painted white, which gives it a really calming atmosphere. The museum has five floors, so there’s quite a bit of walking involved, but there’s a lot to see.The collection is quite varied. You start with Italian sculptures on the lower floor, then move through different exhibits with paintings, historical pieces, and even things like old telephones and communication displays. It’s kind of a mix of art and history, which made it quite fun to explore.If you’re into museums or just want to check out an interesting building and spend a few hours indoors, it’s a solid choice—and it’s free, which is always a bonus.

Review: Loved this visit! We did not get a guide, just read the descriptions and wandered around. I can read Spanish, and my partner used the Google translate app that worked well. I could have spent more time here but we were trying to make it to another place in el Centro. Give yourself at least 3 hours as the museum is pretty big (in addition to to the walk around the exterior ruins!) We bought tickets the same day and were able to use our credit card. Word to the wise- bring a ziploc with paper towels, napkins and wet wipes in a book bag or fanny pack. The public restrooms barely have any (their septic system also doesn’t appreciate any of those items in the toilet bowl!) Also, the one in Templo Mayor is free but most public restrooms charged 5-7 pesos (about a US quarter) just to get inside.

Titulo: A journey to the centre of the Aztec People.
Review: Wonderful experience to understand the culture and society of the Aztec People. Situated in the middle of Mexico City, beside the National Cathedral, this outdoor/indoor museum takes you right back in history. The museum starts outside displaying the internal chambers of the Aztec Temple. As you move through the complex you can see statues, internal seating areas and  temple decorations. The indoor museum holds more unique treasures from the complex including the offering lanterns that were found during repair work to the Cathedral. This discovery inspired further excavations of the Templo Mayor. A wonderful way to understand the unique and dynamic history of the Mexican Indigenous communities.

Review: Very nice museum full of wonderful artifacts. Layout is a bit confusing because you have to leave the main entry room to see any of the good stuff: once past the ticket check, there is a small and underwhelming room but also a side exit that takes you to a walkway around the exterior pyramid remains which then takes you to a massive exhibit area. a bunch of the exterior walk way was closed for us so we didn't see some of those nice skulls i see online. the main exhibit area is pretty great and takes a couple hours to see. There is a really nice gift shop on the outside walkway that we enjoyed. There was a guy outside handing out flyers about the museum and when we politely declined to take one he insulted us. Not sure what his deal was.

Review: Although this site is historically significant, a center piece of Aztec culture in Mexico City.  Walking around the excavation that goes on here, however,  is not very exciting as the jumble of stone is not visually appealing.   But the museum on the property that you encounter after walking halfway around the excavation is amazing.  It is a more modern museum that displays not only artifacts found at this site but also contains lots of information about Aztec life at the time of the conquest.  You can find some of the same info at the large anthropology museum in Chapultapec, but we still loved the singular focus of this museum which contains the statuary found at this site.  We spent a good hour here.  It is important to note that it is customary for the Aztec, like other native groups in mesoAmerica to build one temple over another so a temple may have 4-7 layers with one temple enclosing another.  If you come here you see evidence of all the temples laid bare which is why it is hard to discern what you are seeing here.  This is why you might want to hire a guide at the site (30 minute tour is the norm), who can illustrate what you are seeing if you can not visualize it yourself.

Review: History, history, and more history.Mexico is packed with fascinating places and amazing historical sites. This temple was found while some telecommunication workers were excavating the ground.Suddenly, they found a huge stone that archeologists knew was situated in a major temple. Today, we can still see many of the objects found and some of the walls and paintings of the Temple.The Azteca built on top of existing temples, and you can see several layers of those constructions.There are still uncovered structures, buried in the heart of Mexico city and excavations are still being conducted under the city.One can only imagine what's still to be found!

Titulo: AMAZING....missing this is like missing The Forum if you go to Rome!!!
Review: I can only say "head bending."  This is a must see top three in Mexico City. The excavation and preservation of the site is world class, particularly that the Spanish tore it down!  The relics that are on display in the museum structure at the back are not to be missed.  It's a 4 story structure, and you don't really get a good sense on the ground floor that it's worth going in, but don't miss it!  Every floor gets better, and you can spend an hour here and you will see critical findings that you don't see at the Anthropology Museum.  I was stunned by how affordable the museum is and how few people were there, as the entrance is obscure as it's underground at the back right corner of the cathedral, and not particularly well marked. However, the museum is NOT the little underground area where the tickets are sold, but the massive 4 story structure on the other side of the temple excavations.

Review: When I checked online, it showed that tickets to Chapultepec Castle were sold out, and I was initially quite disappointed. But we decided to visit Chapultepec Park anyway—and I’m so glad we did!The park is absolutely beautiful, with lovely shaded paths and so much greenery. A real highlight was feeding the squirrels—such a unique and joyful experience that we’d never get to do back home.As we explored, we also stopped by the Anthropology Museum, which was stunning and incredibly vast. While the exhibits were impressive, most of the information was in Spanish, so we couldn’t fully appreciate everything.Eventually, we made our way to Chapultepec Castle, and to our surprise, they were selling tickets at the entrance! We bought them and went in right away. Just a heads-up—the walk up to the castle is fairly steep and long, so wear comfortable shoes and be prepared for a bit of a workout.The castle itself is beautiful, filled with rich history and artifacts. I’m really glad we didn’t give up and decided to walk up to the entrance anyway.Important tip: No food or water is allowed inside. They check bags at the top, and if you’ve brought any, they’ll ask you to throw it away—even if you’ve made it past the entrance. Lockers are available at the bottom, so it’s best to store your items there before heading up.

Titulo: Crowded, but worthwhile if you can tolerate the cattle line jostling
Review: The museum is what it is, an interesting place that is so crowded with visitors that it is uncomfortable. I don’t read Spanish well so details were lost on me, but I’ve read a biography on Kahlo so I got the gist. HOWEVER, this review is mostly to caution people against booking through TA. For a few weeks the time was 1:30 pm. The day before the event I got an alert that it was 1 pm. We got to the museum early to avoid traffic, wait in line and BOOM the ticket wranglers tell us it’s for 1:30, not 1. So back in the cattle line we go.I’m glad I went— I liked seeing the house and several objects and paintings, but I will never want to go again. Also, i will never book anything through TA again (I had a negative experience regarding time with a booking yesterday, too). Happy travels.

Titulo: Great experience for Frida and art lovers!
Review: Loved this trip! It was about a half hour Uber ride from Roma Norte. I bought my ticket online, about 3 weeks in advance. The tickets were mailed to us and I easily pulled them up on my phone.  We showed up 15 minutes in advance and there was a line. I did a self guided tour and we spent about 2 hours on the grounds. I was able to see all the spaces and if you want to eat in the cafe, give yourself some more time. We went walking to the Mercado de Coyoacán afterwards to eat!

Review: Must-do for Mexico City. So many interesting pieces from Frida's life to be found here. Definitely book your ticket in advance online. We went on a Tuesday and by 11 am, all entries until 4 pm were sold out. Luckily, we had booked our tickets online 2 weeks earlier but even then, time slots only had 1 or 2 available spots left. There are good souvenir kiosks outside the museum but they require cash. There are nice souvenirs inside but they get picked over quick and seem to take a while to replenish due to the crowds. A great art studio right next door to the museum too. (Can't recall the name.) The entryway alone is a fabulous photo-op but upstairs there are lots of interesting crafts, jewelry, art, etc that aren't super expensive. They will tell you all about how the pieces were made.Getting a photo at Casa Azul without randoms standing in the background is hard considering how packed it was. There is a small drink cart inside the grounds and lots of sitting areas so plan to have a drink and relax for a while within the blue walls after visiting the museum/ home.

Titulo: Wonderful place to personally connect with Mexico’s most famous artist.
Review: A great musuem to explore the beauty and tragedy of Mexico’s most celebrated modern artist. Frida Kahlo grew up in this home and having survived polio, she had her right leg amputated after a tragic bus accident. The museum carefully displays 21 of her more minor works but gives a wonderful narrative of her life, politics, and marriage to Diego Rivera. This exhibit also includes personal items including the bed (with suspended mirror) that she used to construct her self portraits as well as the room where she passed away. A newer addition to the collection is some of her wonderful clothes that were discovered in the house in 2007. Pre-book your tickets in advance is essential for entry.

The museum carefully displays 21 of her more minor works but gives a wonderful narrative of her life, politics, and marriage to Diego Rivera. Review: We bought our tickets about 49 days in advance and would recommend to get the first slot in the morning (10 AM) to beat the crowds. People start lining up about 15-30 minutes before their scheduled time. You cannot go at another time, you have to go at the time stated on your ticket. We had printed tickets and saved a screenshot in our phones. The QR code ticket screenshot in our phones were read easier than the printed version. Make sure you see the last part of the museum! After Frida Kahlo's death in 1954, her husband Diego Rivera had her belongings stored in a bathroom at their home, and ordered it to remain locked until 15 years after his own death. The room was opened in 2004, fifty years after it was sealed and the contents are showcased in that last area.

Review: As an art lover and admirer of Frida it was the first place I visited in the city.  Definitely worth visiting.  I was expecting a crush of people and vendors but it was not like that. The flow of people was well organized , not crowded and the area was really nice and not at all commercialized.   We decided to get there early because the traffic is so heavy and enjoyed fresh juices at a sidewalk cafe while we waited. Must buy tickets in advance.

Titulo: Fridas life? Sort of. Artwork? Less so.
Review: So if you’re a mega fan or a member of the Cult of Frida (which is a thing as far as I can tell) then this is a cool experience. You get to walk through the house where she lived most of her life with and without Diego.  But, if you’re just a mid range fan (which I admittedly am) you may feel a little short changed. There are a handful (a small handful at that) of Frida’s paintings. Like 4 or 5? So not much “art” when you think of a museum dedicated to a famous artist. But the other stuff - living quarters, her various medical recovery implements, even some of her clothes - are interesting enough. Just lot sure why this is the toughest museum ticket in CDMX. Take a pre tour - without it, the small museum would have been lest interesting.

Review: Don’t be late for your assigned time! Don’t let the long line concern you. Groups of ten are allowed in every few minutes. Since the entrance includes important info to read, it gets too crowded to read the material.  This s a design and flow error that needs correction to increase enjoyment and improve visitor experience.Once through that cluster, the situation improves. The compound has large, lush interior gardens open to the sky.  The rooms include original items and furnishings. It is wonderful to see Frida’s beautiful outfits, always long due to polio and a lower limb amputation after a serious accident.It is heartbreaking to see her surgical corsets and partial body casts, her wheelchair poised before her easel, and her leg brace.

Titulo: Be sure to visit when in Mexico City
Review: Visiting the Frida Kahlo museum is a definite "must do" when visiting Mexico City. The house and compound themselves are breathtakingly beautiful. The content of the house is fascinating and so very interesting - an homage to an extraordinary woman and artist. Be sure to buy tickets in advance.

Review: This is an amazing place to visit. It is like traveling back in time and be part of her day to day life. The house is kept in its original condition and also features original Frida’s paintings. Due to it’s popularity all tickets get sold online and run out quickly, so, plan ahead.

Titulo: Museo Frida Kahlo, Mexico City in October
Review: Book in advance! We turned up thinking we could stroll in on a Sunday in October but next available date was the Tuesday. Easy enough to book online though, you book a time , you get a 15 minute window if you are late, and once in courtyard you go through with your timed group where you can then go off at own pace. The museum was ok, but you need to be a big fan to appreciate everything. The gardens were relaxing to sit in, the gift shop was not very good, there was another gift shop stall by exit which had some other bits. Also by the exit was the dress museum which I found more interesting than the house.

Review: You come to this museum if you are interested in learning about the Great Mexican painter Frida Kalho and the world famous painter Diego Rivera her husband.  When Frida died her house that she shared with Diego for 25 years was opened  to the public.  A visit here requires advance purchased tickets and because the house rooms are small, timed entrances.   When you come you are directed through the rooms of her/their house and then into the gardens.  In a separate area there is another small exhibition area where Frida’s clothes are displayed.  There is also a small snack shop on the property.  As Frida and Diego spent so much time here and were international figures with many friends, the house reflects so much of their personality.  We spent 1.5 hours here.  The tickets you purchase (seniors get free entrance), also allow you to visit for free the Museo Anachuacalli.  Anachuacalli is a museum built by Diego and Frida to house his collection of Precolumbian Art.  The art collection is good but the museum architecture is the real reason for a visit.  Built like a temple building you might find at Teotihucan, it is quite unique and provides a view over Mexico City.   If you are staying in downtown Mexico City, keep in mind that the Khalo house (aka Casa Azul) is 25 minutes away in Coyacan and the Anachuacalli is 13 minutes by car further out of town.  So if you wish to do both, plan on doing so in one day.  Lastly, if you are a history buff don’t miss the Leon Trotsky house which is a few blocks away from the Khalo House.  Leon Trotsky was assassinated in his house and it can be visited.

Review: The museum demands pre.online ticket booking. On the spot tickets are impossible to get. Even with prior appointment, 15-30 minutes of wait is possible. It has lots of items: family photos, school progress reports, newspaper articles, beds, clothes and dresses, crutches and vessels. Amidst all these are just a few surreal paintings of real beauty. They speak for the talent of the artist, condone the stories of hysterics, malingerings and peculiarities.

Titulo: Worth every penny and every minute
Review: Beautifully done, wonderful presentation of Frida's story, her art, her home, and her life with Diego Rivera.  So glad I took the time to come here for a visit.

Review: Frida Kahlo (1907-1954) was eminent Mexican artist who married Diego Rivero, a famous painter. Frida Kahlo is known for her self-portraits and her paintings of natural Mexican subjects. Frida Kahlo is known for her unique beauty; she suffered from polio and accidents but emerged as one of the great feminist artists of the 20th Century. Many of her works are held in public collections in Mexico and overseas.

Titulo: Over rated and hard to schedule a visit for a group
Review: Over rated and hard to schedule a visit for a group. Their system only lets you get 5 tickets. And we were a group of 6. We had to buy tickets for two different times. And the website does not tell you can use the earlier ticket at the later time. We bought 5 tickets for 3:15 and we had to buy one for 3:45.   They would not let all 6 of us go in together as a group and wanted one of us to go at 3:45.  And the people working the line etc were acting all mighty about it. It is basically a system to control how many people are walking the place. Not a pleasant experience.  Maybe if you are a die hard artist you would have to go.  This was by a far for us a time not well spent.  There are more entertaining museums, parks and events. Waste of my money.They were letting other people just go in with the same issue but they were with a guide.  A rigged system.

Review: Highly recommend taking a tour with this site, so you have some background context to the house and life of Frida Kahlo. Trust, it will impact the way you take in the house! Exhibits are well done and powerful. The location, in the neighborhood of Coyoacán, is spectacular. There’s a lot of food, artisans, and monuments to explore in this area - you could spend the whole day checking out various markets and sites!
